prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: The Panel Rules do not expressly provide for rehearing or reconsideration of Panel decisions. These motions are available, although they are discouraged by the Panel just as they are by all courts.[1] The rules do explicitly acknowledge them by in providing that no hearing will be allowed for them.[2] The mere fact that the rules do not provide for them does not render them unavailable or inappropriate, and few courts specifically provide for reconsideration by rule. The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure make no reference to such motions. The Panel has granted reconsideration and rehearing in a few cases.[3]

Reconsideration and rehearing on the same facts and record should be distinguished from resubmission of matters to the Panel following further development of the facts, the occurrence of intervening events, or changes in the law. These matters may always be submitted to the Panel for consideration since Panel decisions, especially those denying transfer, are generally not made with prejudice.[4] Motions for reconsideration or rehearing may seek:
To obtain a statement of specific bases or grounds for the earlier decision;
To present a new argument or one better tuned to the Panel's now-disclosed views of the litigation;
To bring intervening legal or factual developments to the attention of the Panel; or
To secure a more favorable ruling or whine about the earlier decision.[5]
The first three of these classes of motions are not likely to be worth the effort of bringing them.

The Panel is especially likely not to need “reargument” because it is a multiple judge tribunal and because oral argument is generally allowed to any party desiring it.[6] The Panel will respond predictably to an effort merely to whine about its recently issued but ill-advised (in the eyes of the disappointed litigant) decision.

Where there are significant factual or legal developments bearing on the transfer issue, however, a motion for reconsideration would be useful. The clearest example is if facts existing but not known at the time the matter was initially heard became known. This would not include the pendency of actions not known at the time of the initial hearing if transfer was ordered, for that situation is governed by the provision for tag-along actions in Panel Rules 7.1 and 7.2.[7]

In one case the Panel granted a motion for reconsideration and ordered transfer of cases after an initial denial four months earlier.[8] The earlier decision had denied transfer of six tag-along actions, although the Panel had previously ordered transfer of some related actions for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.[9] The Panel noted three developments occurring after its earlier decision that justified reconsideration: the certification of a class by the transferee court in the actions initially transferred, the request by the transferee judge that the tag-along actions be transferred, and the execution of a settlement agreement in the class action.[10] A special variant of a motion for reconsideration or rehearing occurs when a party seeks retransfer. Retransfer is discussed in greater detail in § 8:7 in the context of selection of the transferee district where tag-along actions are transferred. The Panel has viewed retransfer in these circumstances as “rehearing,” however.[11]

“Reconsideration” can also occur when the Panel considers a second motion for transfer in a group of cases. Because denial of a motion for transfer is made without prejudice,[12] a second motion can always be entertained by the Panel.[13] In some cases, the Panel has even encouraged the parties to reapply for transfer if future developments favoring transfer take place.[14]

The Panel has considered requests for modification of its transfer orders and has entered appropriate modified orders. In one case the Panel had ordered transfer of the majority of the claims in the cases under consideration, but had remanded certain cases to a different district because a settlement of those claims had been reached in that district. When the parties brought to the Panel's attention the fact that claims against additional subsidiaries, affiliates, franchisees, and related entities had also been settled, the Panel modified its order, remanding claims against those parties as well.[15]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
Motions for reconsideration are discussed in greater detail in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Motion Practice§ 3.8 (8th ed. 2018).
